member.name: T:SySal.OperaPersistence
member.summary: Opera persistence class. Supports seamless persistence of large data objects to files / OperaDB.

remarks.para: This class is at the foundation of the Grand Unified File System (GUFS). GUFS unifies file access and DB access, so that data in the DB are accessed with a file-like path.
Files retain their path syntax (be it a local or network path); objects stored in the DB are found at subdirectories of db:\ that is the metaphoric disk unit on which DB data reside.
The extension of the GUFS file name is important for OperaPersistence, as it defines the data type.

One difference survives between files and DB data: for some data types, the identifier is generated by the DB upon insertion, and is unknown a priori. Therefore, the write path is different from the read path: e.g. on writing a LinkedZone to the DB one fills the relevant information fields, but the Id is unknown, and is actually returned as an output by the insertion procedure.

Path syntax for Raw Data Catalogs
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0023.rwc, \\datasrv.mysite.eu\datashare\plate_0023.rwc
DB read pathN/A
DB write pathN/A

Path syntax for Raw Data Fragments
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0023.rwd, c:\mydata\plate_0023.rwd.00000008, \\datasrv.mysite.eu\datashare\plate_0023.rwd
DB read pathN/A
DB write pathN/A

Path syntax for LinkedZones
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0023.tlg, \\datasrv.mysite.eu\datashare\plate_0023.tlg
DB read pathThe brick id and zone id are required. Example: db:\8\277801335.tlg
DB write pathThe brick id, plate id, process operation, series, raw data path, start time and end time are required. Example: db:\8\139903233\139903188\834\'\\myserver.mysite.eu\datashare\myzone'\'8/11/2008 11:53:08'\'8/11/2008 12:08:24'.tlg

Path syntax for DBMIPMicroTrackIndex
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0008.tlg
DB read pathN/A
DB write pathN/A

Path syntax for BaseTrackIgnoreAlignment
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0008.tlg
DB read pathN/A
DB write pathN/A

Path syntax for BaseTrackIndex
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0008.tlg
DB read pathN/A
DB write pathN/A

Path syntax for SlopeCorrections
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\plate_0008.tlg
DB read pathN/A
DB write pathN/A

Path syntax for TotalScan Reconstructions
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\event_512.tsr, \\datasrv.mysite.eu\datashare\event_512.tsr
DB read pathThe brick id, reconstruction id and option id are required. Example: db:\8\13874388\2.tsr
DB write pathThe brick id, process operation id and option id are required. Example: db:\8\18004300\5.tsr

Path syntax for ProgramSettings
FilesStandard OS paths. Examples: c:\mydata\predscan01.xml, \\datasrv.mysite.eu\datashare\predscan01.xml
DB read pathThe program settings id is required. Example: db:\832388.xml
DB write pathThe executable, description, driverlevel and template marks usage are required. The driver level must appear as a number (0 - Lowest, 1 - Scanning, 2 - Volume, 3 - Brick, 4 - System); for template mark set usage, 0 means 'uses calibrated marks', nonzero means 'uses nominal marks'. Example: db:\'PredictionScan3Driver.exe'\'Prediction scanning for OPERA Scanback'\1\0.xml
NOTICE: program settings written to the DB in this way will be recorded as being produced by the author specified by the current default access credentials obtained from .
